Writing values
With Proctal not only can you read the contents in memory straight from your terminal, you can also easily modify them. The write command is able to write text, integers, IEEE754 floating point numbers, CPU instructions and more.
The command accepts type parameters. You can find out all about them here.
Here's how you would write a 32-bit integer with the value 0 at the memory address 7FFE79DEA90C in a program whose PID is 12345.
$ proctal write --pid=12345 --address=7FFE79DEA90C --type=integer --integer-size=32 0
Writing arrays
But what if you had an array of 32-bit integers in memory? One way to write all the elements would be to execute the write command at the corresponding address for each element. But a better way is to take advantage of the --array parameter. It takes the number of elements as its value.
Here's how you would write an array of 5 32-bit integers.
$ proctal write --pid=12345 --address=7FFE79DEA90C --type=integer --integer-size=32 --array=5 0 0 0 0 0
You can also let the command loop back to the first value if you don't provide the same number of values as the array parameter. This means that the previous command is equivalent to this one:
$ proctal write --pid=12345 --address=7FFE79DEA90C --type=integer --integer-size=32 --array=5 0
Repeat writing
With the --repeat parameter you can make the command repeatedly write the same values over and over again. With the --repeat-delay parameter you can even specify the delay in milliseconds between writes.
The command will keep running until you tell it to stop. You can stop it by sending it the SIGINT signal (^C on most terminals).
By default the delay is set to be 5 milliseconds.
